message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the properties of ice and the concept of phase changes. When ice is heated, it undergoes a phase change from a solid to a liquid, resulting in a puddle of water. Option (A) is incorrect because heating ice does not change its chemical make-up, it only changes its physical state. Option (C) is incorrect because a deep freezer is used to freeze things, not to heat them. Option (D) is incorrect because heating ice will actually cause it to become warmer, not colder.

This question requires basic knowledge about the properties of water and the phase changes it undergoes. When ice is heated, it melts and changes from a solid to a liquid form. This will result in a puddle of water. Option (A) is incorrect because heating ice does not change its chemical make-up; it only changes its physical state. Option (C) is unrelated because a deep freezer is not necessary for heating ice. Option (D) is also incorrect because heating ice will not make it colder; it will make it warmer and eventually cause it to melt.

This question requires basic knowledge about the physical properties of ice and the process of heating. When ice is heated, it undergoes a phase change from solid to liquid, turning into water. This will result in a puddle because the ice has melted. Option (A) is incorrect because heating ice does not change its chemical makeup, it only changes the state of matter. Option (C) is incorrect because a deep freezer is not necessary to heat ice, any source of heat will work. Option (D) is incorrect because heating ice will make it warmer, not colder.

Option (A) is incorrect because heating ice does not change its chemical make-up, it simply changes its physical state. Option (C) is incorrect because a deep freezer is used to freeze items, not to heat them. Option (D) is incorrect because when ice is heated, it becomes warmer, not colder.
